posts.name: Pedro Lima
posts.cooked: In recent years, the majority of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) stores have started selling their own Swerve Drive Modules, leading to numerous options available in the market. However, we became unsure of which module to choose. Currently, we are utilizing the Swerve Drive Specialties (SDS) mk4i module, but we have encountered issues with the angulating belt, breaking whenever the Kraken X60 power exceeds 70%. After visiting other teams at Champs, we noticed that each team uses a different module, further increasing our uncertainty. What Swerve module would provide the best performance with a reliable drive train?

posts.name: Andrew Card
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text, adhering to the specified requirements:

"While I have heard reports of belts breaking on MK4i modules, this is usually after an extreme amount of use. If you are breaking belts regularly, something else may be an issue. That being said, the WCP X2 modules or the upcoming SDS MK5 module have gear for the module steering. In general, changing from MK4i to a newer module is unlikely to impact robot performance substantially. Depending on how tight your budget is, money could easily be better invested elsewhere."

posts.name: Samuel
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

Having the belt break that easily on the MK4I sounds like extreme amounts of use or something else acting up. That being said, the WCP X2 line only uses gears, and the upcoming SDS Mk5 doesn’t either. I don’t think upgrading swerve is worth it unless you have a lot of money to throw at problems. MK4I are great, and they have an upgrade path with the chassis lowering block and the MK4N kit. You can also consider printed Swerve as an alternative to billet wheels for a higher wheel CoF and much easier swaps.

posts.name: Pedro Lima
posts.cooked: We aren’t sure what’s going on with our Mk4i Swerve modules; however, we’ve observed that several teams on Champs utilize 100% Kraken modules for driving and angulating, including those with custom Kraken modules that operate at 130% capacity. Despite this, none of these teams have reported belt issues. We’re uncertain if the problem stems from the drivetrain size, robot weight, or another factor. However, we’ve encountered broken belts on three or four occasions, and we’re unable to identify the cause. As a result, we’re considering upgrading to a Swerve module that doesn’t rely on belts.

posts.name: Samuel
posts.cooked: If the belt isn't properly seated or clogged with debris, or if the pulley is off-center or worn out—which could also mean it's misaligned or damaged—the strange wear pattern remains puzzling. Conducting a detailed examination and thoroughly checking each component—ensuring they're correctly aligned and free from dirt—could resolve the issue or clarify exactly what's wrong. However, without a closer inspection of the affected areas, it's unlikely we'll have a definitive answer.

posts.name: Daniel
posts.cooked: The Mk4i series has proven reliable, with only minor issues encountered during testing, particularly involving Kraken units in the last two models. We thoroughly maintain our swerves, and there haven’t been any significant issues observed. The only minor drawback is that these models feature a smaller chassis, which can be inconvenient.

posts.name: Pedro Lima
posts.cooked: Do you know the proportion of Kraken power used in each Kraken? Because we inspected multiple times, it doesn't seem to have any issues with the installation, but the belt still breaks.
